repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:  Combined highlighting was not applied to nvim_eval_statusline(),
          and 'statuscolumn' sign segment/numhl highlights.
Solution: Add an additional `groups` element to the return value of
          `nvim_eval_statusline()->highlights`. This is an array of stacked
          highlight groups (highest priority last). Also resolve combined
          highlights for the 'statuscolumn' sign segment/numhl highlights.
          Expose/synchronize some drawline.c logic that is now mimicked in
          three different places.

Followup to #29976, #31575

comment_data.body:
With this, would/can we deprecate `group` (now/ever)?
I also considered omitting `groups` from the return value when there is only 1 group, so no stacking, but always including it is probably worth it for simplicity sake.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -704,6 +704,8 @@ nvim_eval_statusline({str}, {opts})                   *nvim_eval_statusline()*
           â€¢ start: (number) Byte index (0-based) of first character that uses
             the highlight.
           â€¢ group: (string) Name of highlight group.
+          â€¢ groups: (array) Names of stacked highlight groups (highest
+            priority last).

comment_data.body:
> With this, would/can we deprecate `group` (now/ever)?

Sure. We don't have a "pattern" for deprecating kwargs fields, but I suggest something like: if the deprecated key is used, call `vim.deprecate(..., '0.13')` using `NLUA_EXEC_STATIC`.

> I also considered omitting `groups` from the return value when there is only 1 group, so no stacking, but always including it is probably worth it for simplicity sake.

Predictability is strongly preferred. Polymorphic returns are painful. So +1 for "always include".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -704,6 +704,8 @@ nvim_eval_statusline({str}, {opts})                   *nvim_eval_statusline()*
           â€¢ start: (number) Byte index (0-based) of first character that uses
             the highlight.
           â€¢ group: (string) Name of highlight group.
+          â€¢ groups: (array) Names of stacked highlight groups (highest
+            priority last).

comment_data.body:
> but I suggest something like: if the deprecated key is used

I don't think detecting that is feasible though? At best we could maybe slap a `---@deprecated` on the return class, but that is currently a generic `table<string,any>` for all `Dict` return types, and I'm not even sure the deprecated annotation can be used for class fields.

EDIT1: https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/issues/1313 seems to both suggest it is and isn't possibleðŸ˜….

EDIT2: No yeah we do it for e.g. `vim.lsp.Client.messages` which does work. So could do that if we update `gen_eval_files.lua` to annotate the actual dict signature.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -704,6 +704,8 @@ nvim_eval_statusline({str}, {opts})                   *nvim_eval_statusline()*
           â€¢ start: (number) Byte index (0-based) of first character that uses
             the highlight.
           â€¢ group: (string) Name of highlight group.
+          â€¢ groups: (array) Names of stacked highlight groups (highest
+            priority last).

comment_data.body:
Oh sorry I thought "group" was a kwargs field, not a return value.

For deprecating return values we can just mention it in its docstring, for now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -704,6 +704,8 @@ nvim_eval_statusline({str}, {opts})                   *nvim_eval_statusline()*
           â€¢ start: (number) Byte index (0-based) of first character that uses
             the highlight.
           â€¢ group: (string) Name of highlight group.
+          â€¢ groups: (array) Names of stacked highlight groups (highest
+            priority last).

comment_data.body:

OK, so should we do that here?

@@ -704,6 +704,8 @@ nvim_eval_statusline({str}, {opts})                   *nvim_eval_statusline()*

             the highlight.
           â€¢ group: (string) Name of highlight group.
+          â€¢ groups: (array) Names of stacked highlight groups (highest
+            priority last).

comment_regular_data.body:
Thanks, @luukvbaal! This indeed fixes combining highlight attributes for line numbers.

There also seems to be a similar issue for signs, though. Here is the repro:

```lua
vim.o.cursorline = true
vim.o.statuscolumn = '%C%s%=%l'

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'CursorLineSign', { underline = true })
vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'Green', { fg = 'NvimLightGreen' })

vim.api.nvim_buf_set_lines(0, 0, -1, false, { 'aaa', 'bbb', 'ccc' })
local ns_id = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('test')
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, ns_id, 0, 0, { sign_text = '!', sign_hl_group = 'Green' })
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, ns_id, 1, 0, { sign_text = '*', sign_hl_group = 'Green' })
```

With this PR it behaves like this (seems to combine with `CursorLineNr` instead of `CursorLineSign`):

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c04b937b-3415-4a0c-bcfa-dfc494bfe446
Yeah I thought as much. That will be less straight-forward to resolve.

Also worth noting that since we now combine highlights, the highlights returned by `nvim_eval_statusline()` are no longer representative of what will actually be drawn. Not sure how that API is most often used, but I know at least `nvim-treesitter-context` uses it to build a statuscolumn from highlighted buffer text in a floating window, whose highlights may now be incorrect. ~~Would have to create some kind of dummy highlight groups if we want to support combined highlights there.~~

EDIT: We can just add the to be combined highlight group to the return value of `nvim_eval_statusline()->highlights`. The above use-case can then place two extmarks on top of each other to achieve the combined highlighting. Updated the PR to do so, now also properly combining the `'statuscolumn'` sign segment.

title: feat(api): combined highlights in nvim_eval_statusline()
